claim: All cats are mammals. Tigers belong to the cat family. Therefore, tigers are mammals

supporting.text: All cats are mammals, and tigers are members of the cat family (Felidae), so by definition, tigers must be mammals.

attacks.text: All cats are mammals, and tigers are members of the cat family (Felidae), so by definition, tigers must be mammals.
Some species historically classified as cats may not fit modern mammalian definitions due to evolving taxonomy.
Hybridization or genetic anomalies could theoretically produce non-mammalian traits in tigers, challenging strict classification.
Modern taxonomy rigorously defines Felidae as mammals, leaving no ambiguity for species like tigers.
No documented cases exist of tigers exhibiting non-mammalian traits; genetic stability is well-established.

supporting.text: The biological classification system places tigers under the order Carnivora, which is a subset of the class Mammalia, confirming tigers as mammals.

attacks.text: The biological classification system places tigers under the order Carnivora, which is a subset of the class Mammalia, confirming tigers as mammals.
Some members of Carnivora, like certain extinct species, may not fit the traditional definition of mammals.
Modern taxonomy strictly defines Carnivora as a mammalian order, excluding non-mammalian species.
Genetic mutations could theoretically lead to non-mammalian traits in Carnivora species, challenging the classification.
No documented cases exist of Carnivora species exhibiting non-mammalian traits, maintaining the validity of the classification.

supporting.text: Tigers exhibit key mammalian traits such as giving live birth, producing milk, and having hair, which are definitive characteristics of mammals.

attacks.text: Tigers exhibit key mammalian traits such as giving live birth, producing milk, and having hair, which are definitive characteristics of mammals.
Some non-mammalian species, like certain sharks, also give live birth, which blurs the distinction between mammals and other animals.
However, the combination of live birth, milk production, and hair is unique to mammals, clearly distinguishing them from other animal classes.
Genetic studies suggest that some traits traditionally associated with mammals may have evolved independently in other groups.
Despite convergent evolution, the specific suite of traits in mammals is still universally recognized as defining the class.
